sections.summary: This range establishes the legal penalty of one hundred lashes for **adultery** and restricts the marriage of those who commit it to others of similar conduct. Believers are commanded not to let pity interfere with the execution of Allah’s Law, which must be witnessed by a group of the faithful.

A penalty of eighty lashes is ordained for those who falsely accuse chaste women without producing four witnesses, rendering their future testimony unacceptable. It also introduces the legal process of **Li’an**, allowing spouses to testify four times by Allah to their truthfulness or the other’s lie to avoid punishment [456–457].

Allah addresses the major **slander (Ifk)** spread by a specific group, emphasizing that believers should think well of one another and refrain from spreading rumors. The text warns that those who love to see **immorality** spread among the believers will face a painful punishment in this world and the Hereafter [457–458].

Believers are prohibited from entering homes other than their own until they have asked **permission** and offered a greeting to the occupants. If no one is present or if they are asked to turn back, they must do so, as this practice is more conducive to purity and **privacy** [458–459].

Believing men and women are commanded to lower their **gaze** and guard their private parts to maintain spiritual purity. Women are specifically instructed to draw their **coverings** over their breasts and to not display their beauty except to their husbands or designated close relatives.

The community is encouraged to facilitate the marriage of singles and righteous servants, with a promise that Allah will enrich them from His **bounty**. It strictly forbids compelling maids into **prostitution** for worldly gains and provides clarifying revelations for those seeking the path of the righteous.

Allah is described through the **Verse of Light**, comparing His guidance to a brilliant lamp within a glass fueled by a blessed tree. This is contrasted with the deeds of disbelievers, which are likened to a **mirage** in a desert or utter darkness in a deep, wave-covered ocean [459–460].

All creatures in the heavens and earth glorify Allah, who controls the movement of **clouds**, the descent of hail, and the alternation of night and day. He created every living creature from **water**, assigning them diverse forms of movement as signs for people who reason [460–461].

The text distinguishes between hypocrites, who turn away from divine judgment, and true believers, who respond with "**We hear and we obey**." Allah promises to make the righteous **successors** on earth, establishing their religion and substituting their fear with security [461–462].

Specific times of **privacy** are mandated for household members before dawn, at noon, and after the evening prayer. Regulations are also provided for women past childbearing and for the lawfulness of sharing meals in the homes of relatives and friends with **good greetings** [462–463].

Believers are characterized as those who do not leave the Messenger during collective affairs without **permission**. The surah concludes by affirming Allah’s absolute **sovereignty** and His knowledge of all human actions, which will be accounted for upon their return to Him.
